advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> MAIL ORDER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Computer assisted mail-order <br><br> As soon as the home computers could communicate easily through modem with large computer sites, the major mail-order companies had the idea to sell products to the computers users. This concept was facilitated in France by the free distribution of the 'Minitel' Videotex terminal that was gradually integrated into home computers. The success gained by this system in France did not have any equal in the rest of the world. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERTISEMENT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>She seems quite happy with her new MB-H1 !<br> Do you think japanese girls used to bring their H1 to school ?!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Page 2 <br><br> "The domestic computer, business class"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>German advert for the Philips Odyssey 200 model.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.dieterkoenig.at/ccc/" target="_blank">Dieter Koening</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert on the Peerless 150 terminal</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> EQUIPED FOR COMPETITION</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert (december 1984)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 84)</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The Laser 200, a Secam color micro-computer really very suprising''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3 (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In March 1983, the price of the assembled version decreased of $20 ($79.95 instead of $99.95)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NLS ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advert from Non-Linear Systems, dated July, 1982 for the KAYCOMP II that was not still called KAYPRO. <br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666"><b>A WORD ABOUT NLS</b><br> Non-Linear Systems, inc. is the originator of the digital voltmeter and an innovative leader in the field of electronic test equipment.<br> Organized in 1952, NLS has been a major supplier of digital voltmeters and ratiometers to large corporations in the aerospace industry. Since 1972, NLS has been consumer directed, providing small, portable multimeters, oscilloscopes, counters, frequency meters, temperature meters. And now, NLS has entered the world of computers with one though - to provide the best value in a small, business, scientific and family computer.</font><br><br> Standard software delivered with the KAYCOMP II: <br><br> - <b>CP/M 2.2</b> - operating system<br> - <b>S/BASIC</b> - Structured Basic compiler<br> - <b>PROFIT PLAN</b> - Electronic worksheet<br> - <b>SELECT</b> - Complete word processing system<br> - <b>TEACH</b> - A self-teaching guide to SELECT </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>From the magazine 'Micro Sistemas' of March 1983 <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.mci.org.br </b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In U.K., at 1986 Christmas period, the 1040 STF was sold £799 + VAT for the 12" monochrome version, and £999 + VAT for the 14" colour version.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.cobit.kit.net" target="_blank">COB-Clube Old Bits</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Micromachine 4000 but a picture of the Micromachine 2000 and 3000 is inserted for reference...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>School teaching with a Goupil 2</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BAKED APPLE</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, October 1981<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of '<a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a>'</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (SEPTEMBER 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSERT - VERSO</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> TANDY 1988 CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.switchtech.us/Tandy1000.html" target="_blank">SWITCHTECH'S Tandy 1000SX page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Einstein's face probably means: Buy a ZX-81 and you will become a new genius...<p class="petitgris">Karl_Heinz - www.sharpmz.org</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ALTAIR CONVENTION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Altair Convention was here announced in the Computer Notes magazine.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>

computer.description:
This strange machine was shown at Comdex in 1987. It was designed for graphics intensive applications taking advantage of the parallel processing capacities of the INMOS transputer.
Two models were sold: one of them was a card which could be connected onto a Mega STf bus expansion to use its peripherals (keyboard, disk, etc.). The other was a computer in which there was a motherboard with a single transputer plus a card which contained all the Atari Mega STf hardware to use its peripherals!
The motherboard included slots to add up to four more processor cards, each with up to four transputers, to enable multiprocessing.
It ran under Helios, an operating system done by the British company Perihelion, derived from UNIX but specially adapted for parallel processing).
A C language was adapted and a parallel processing language called OCCAM. Only few of these computers were sold, most of them to Kodak.
computer.name: Abaq ATW Transputer 800

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ATW TRANSPUTERS AT KODAK'S</strong></font><br><blockquote>This photo was "secretly" taken at a Kodak-owned facility, notice all the Mega ST keyboards linked to a ATW station (once again obtained through classified sources).</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MY ATARI ATW 800 TRANSPUTER</strong></font><br><blockquote>The picture of the main page shows the Atari Transputer card plugged onto a Mega STf. This photo shows the 'real' Atari ATW 800 Transputer station. There are only 250 (!) transputers in the world ! The 50 first models are prototypes and the 200 other ones were sold to Kodak. My (Thierry speaking here) transputer belongs to the 50 prototypes.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> THE ATARI ATW 800 MOTHER BOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>There are three boards in the ATW : the front card is the Atari STf motherboard, & has all the features of the Atari Mega STf 4, except its SCSI port. The board on the background is the ATW board, the yellow chip is the Inmos T800 CPU. Between the two cards, there is a video card with 1 MB RAM.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ATW 800 OFFICIAL PROMO PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Marcus Baum for this picture</p></blockquote>
